Literature Review: The study of men and masculinities has undergone significant transformations over the past few decades, particularly within the field of anthropology. This literature review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the current state of research, highlighting key developments and theoretical advancements since the early 2000s. The review will also reflect on the extent to which anthropologists have moved beyond binary frameworks to explore gender, sex, and sexuality in more nuanced and inclusive ways. One of the most notable trends in recent years has been the increasing number of ethnographic studies focused on men and masculinities, particularly those authored by anthropologists from the Global South. These studies have brought new perspectives and insights to the field, challenging dominant Western-centric narratives and broadening our understanding of how masculinity is constructed and performed in diverse cultural contexts (Connell, 2005; Kimmel, 2006). For instance, Connell's work on hegemonic masculinity has been influential in shaping the discourse around power relations and gender inequalities, while Kimmel's research has highlighted the complexities of male identity and the ways in which men navigate societal expectations. In addition to these ethnographic contributions, there has been a growing interest in exploring the intersections of masculinity with other social categories, such as race, class, and sexuality. This intersectional approach has enriched our understanding of how multiple forms of oppression and privilege intersect to shape men's experiences and identities (hooks, 2004; Messner, 2000). For example, hooks' work on black masculinity has shed light on the unique challenges faced by African American men, while Messner's research on white working-class masculinity has explored the tensions between economic marginalization and traditional notions of manhood. Another important area of development has been the study of masculinity in relation to public health. Research in this domain has highlighted the ways in which gender norms and expectations can impact men's health behaviors and outcomes. For instance, Courtenay (2000) has argued that hegemonic masculinity can lead to risk-taking behaviors and reluctance to seek medical help, contributing to higher rates of morbidity and mortality among men. Similarly, Krieger (2003) has emphasized the importance of addressing gender inequalities in healthcare policies and practices to improve men's health outcomes. The relationship between masculinity and militarism has also received increased attention in recent years. Studies in this area have examined how military institutions and practices reinforce and perpetuate certain forms of masculinity, often at the expense of more diverse and inclusive understandings of gender (Enloe, 2000; Macdonald, 2007). Enloe's work on the gendered dynamics of war and peace has been particularly influential, while Macdonald's research on the experiences of male soldiers has provided valuable insights into the ways in which military service shapes men's identities and relationships. Anthropologists have also made significant contributions to the study of masculinity through innovative research in biological and linguistic anthropology. Biological anthropologists have explored the evolutionary and physiological underpinnings of masculine behavior, providing a deeper understanding of the biological bases of gender differences (Lynn, 2006; Wood, 2009). Linguistic anthropologists, on the other hand, have examined the role of language and communication in constructing and maintaining masculine identities (Eckert & McConnell-Ginet, 2003; Bucholtz & Hall, 2004). Eckert and McConnell-Ginet's work on gender and language has been particularly influential, while Bucholtz and Hall's research has highlighted the ways in which linguistic practices can both reinforce and challenge gender norms. Finally, the rise of trans* social movements has prompted anthropologists to reconsider the binary frameworks that have traditionally dominated the study of gender and sexuality. This shift has led to a greater focus on the fluidity and diversity of gender identities and expressions, as well as the ways in which these are shaped by cultural and historical contexts (Butler, 1990; Valentine, 2007). Butler's concept of gender performativity has been particularly influential in this regard, while Valentine's research on transgender communities has provided valuable insights into the lived experiences of individuals who do not conform to traditional gender norms. In conclusion, the study of men and masculinities in anthropology has evolved significantly over the past few decades, reflecting broader shifts in the field towards more intersectional and inclusive approaches. While much progress has been made, there is still a need for continued critical engagement with the concepts of gender, sex, and sexuality, and for further exploration of the ways in which these intersect with other social categories. As anthropologists continue to push the boundaries of this field, it is essential to remain open to new perspectives and to engage with the diverse voices and experiences that shape our understanding of masculinity.
